awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CT-T: A Vertical Systems Framework for Effective Defense against Memory-Based Attacks
awd_abstract_narration:
The security of national information infrastructures is undermined by constant malicious attacks exploiting vulnerabilities in systems software. Most existing attacks exploit memory-based flaws, such as stack or heap overflows, and format string vulnerabilities. Current defense mechanisms, either network- or host-based, are not sufficient against many advanced attacks such as polymorphic or metamorphic worm exploits. This project is to provide a comprehensive framework for detecting, analyzing, and exterminating such attacks. The PIs take an interdisciplinary approach, combining their expertise in computer architecture, computer and network security, programming languages, compilers, and software engineering to tackle this difficult problem. 
In particular, the PIs propose a layered defense and analysis framework that consists of: (1) an architecture layer for detecting and recovering from unknown attacks; (2) an analysis layer for diagnosing attacks and generating attack signatures; and (3) a testing layer for discovering and fixing unknown software vulnerabilities. The intellectual merit of this project will lie in the advanced techniques developed in this project to defend against unknown, large-scale memory-based attacks. 

This interdisciplinary project will allow an effective approach to tackle this problem and advance knowledge in each of the requisite disciplines with both systems concepts and advanced programming language and analysis techniques. The broader impact of this project is the potential for a more reliable and secure information systems infrastructure. This will have tremendous economical impact on society because of our growing reliance on information technologies. Research results from this project (such as systems, simulators, and tools) will be widely disseminated so that they can be further evaluated, enhanced, and adopted to benefit other researchers and the industry.

por.por_cntn:
For the duration of this project, we, the principal investigators and
graduate students, have investigated novel and practical techniques to
detect, analyze, and prevent vulnerabilities and attacks. The
conducted research and education activities have advanced our
understanding regarding attack detection and prevention, helped to
discover many serious vulnerabilities in widely-deployed software, and
trained next generation security researchers and engineers. More
specifically,

- We have developed techniques to analyze and recover from attacks
that can be used to take full control of vulnerable systems.

- We have developed techniques to analyze and detect stealthy
malicious software (malware), which typically employs various
strategies to evade detection.

- We have developed techniques to cluster malware variants and
generate simple, precise signatures for effective malware detection
and analysis.

- We have developed effective testing and analysis techniques that
have been used to uncover serious vulnerabilities in popular Windows
software and Web applications, thus significantly improving the
security of existing software and systems.

- We have substantially advanced our knowledge regarding software
security by investigating new types of vulnerabilities, and inventing
new techniques to detect attacks and vulnerabilities.

- We have disseminated our research results through publications in
top outlets such as highly-competitive conferences and premium
journals, public tool releases, and research exchanges.

- We have successfully trained the next generation computer security
experts (four PhD graduates) through graduate student advising and
engineers through undergraduate and graduate level education.
